comment.text: This translation key is used to display a button or label that indicates actions available in an article or profile section. It appears on a main button and in some header sections, where it shows a title such as "Actions" or "Invite", depending on the context.

usage.context:
<div className="action-button">
 {(isAdmin && !profile?.isOwner) ||
 (!profile?.isLDAP && !profile?.isSSO) ? (
 <ContextMenuButton
 directionX="right"
 title={t("Common:Actions")}
 iconName={VerticalDotsReactSvgUrl}
 size={17}
 getData={getUserContextOptions}
 isDisabled={false}
 usePortal

ai_spell_check_issues.description: 'Actions' can have multiple Korean translations depending on the context. '작업' (jak-up) generally means 'work' or 'task', which isn't always the best fit for 'Actions' in a UI/software context. Alternatives like '행동' (haeng-dong - action) or '동작' (dong-jak - movement/action) might be more accurate, but require understanding the specific usage of 'Actions'.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider alternatives like '행동' or '동작', or further context to determine the most appropriate translation.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: While "ການດໍາເນີນການ" is a valid Lao word, it's a rather formal and literal translation of "Actions."  It doesn't quite capture the nuance of the English term, which can imply a range of actions, not just 'operations' or 'procedures'. A more natural translation might be something like "ການກະເຮັດ" or "ປະຕິບັດງານ", depending on the context.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider "ການກະເຮັດ" or "ປະຕິບັດງານ" as potentially more appropriate alternatives, depending on context.  Further context would help determine the most suitable translation.
